batting_grip.title: Batting Grip (V–Grip)
batting_grip.what: The method of holding the cricket bat using both hands for maximum control and swing efficiency.
how_to: Stand the bat upright in front of your body.
Place your top hand high on the handle with fingers wrapped — not palm.
Form a 'V' shape between the thumb and index finger.
Ensure the top-hand 'V' points between splice and inside edge.
Place bottom hand lightly below the top hand — controlling direction, not power.
Check both hands working together — not independently.
batting_grip.why_it_matters: Correct grip improves control, timing, bat face alignment, ability to play straight, reduces wrist rigidity and prevents injury.
mistakes: Holding bat with palm instead of fingers.
V pointing outside edge — leading to slicing shots.
drills: Bottom-hand looseness practice using towel wrap.

batting_stance.title: Batting Stance
batting_stance.what: The foundation body position before ball release.
how_to: Stand side-on to bowler.
Feet shoulder-width apart, parallel.
Knees slightly flexed.
Weight evenly distributed on balls of feet.
Head still, eyes level facing bowler.
Bat resting behind back foot.
Elbows relaxed.
Front shoulder pointing towards bowler.
batting_stance.why_it_matters: Correct stance improves balance, shot selection, speed of footwork and reduces movement errors.
mistakes: Feet too narrow or too wide.
drills: Stance hold time practice 3 x 30 seconds

backlift.title: Backlift
backlift.what: Raising the bat in preparation for playing a shot.
how_to: Lift the bat as the bowler loads into action.
Lift with relaxed wrists.
Backlift angle slightly open to slip region.
Keep bat weight controlled — not heavy.
Keep hands close to body, not away.
Lead shoulder must turn slightly inward.
backlift.why_it_matters: Improves swing path, timing, control, shot power, and prevents late bat movements.
mistakes: Bat lifted behind head — delayed downswing.

trigger_movement.title: Trigger Movement
trigger_movement.what: Initial movement before ball release to help timing.
how_to: Start movement as bowler plants front foot.
Small step back or across — not large.
Maintain balance through centre.
Keep head still while feet initiate.
Repeat same trigger every ball.
trigger_movement.why_it_matters: A trigger movement activates muscles, improves reaction speed and shot timing.

footwork.title: Footwork Basics
footwork.what: Movement of feet for shot execution — forward, backward, lateral.
how_to: Push weight from hips not knees.
Move first, swing later.
Front foot towards pitch of ball.
Back foot movement for short length.
Stay light on balls of feet.
Low centre of gravity on movement.
footwork.why_it_matters: Footwork generates balance, timing, control and increases shot selection range.
mistakes: Using knee push instead of hip drive.
